name: Storycatcher II
description: A JavaScript project, designed for managing, capturing, or present stories.

aiSpecRequirements.title: User Registration and Authentication
aiSpecRequirements.description: The system shall allow new users to register and existing users to log in securely, forming the initial entry point to the application as per the 'Landing Page', 'Login Page', and 'Registration Page' specifications. This is critical for personalized story archiving.

aiSpecRequirements.title: AI-Guided Interview Assistant
aiSpecRequirements.description: The system shall provide an AI-guided interview process based on the 5W questioning method, facilitating the capture of personal stories. This includes prompting users with relevant questions after audio segments are processed.

aiSpecRequirements.title: Voice-to-Text Transcription (Local-First)
aiSpecRequirements.description: The system shall perform voice-to-text transcription of recorded audio segments using local-first STT engines (Whisper or Vosk). This is crucial for processing interviews and maintaining GDPR compliance by keeping data on the device.

aiSpecRequirements.title: Interactive Story Capture Loop
aiSpecRequirements.description: The frontend shall implement an interactive loop allowing users to record audio segments, send them for processing, display the analysis (transcript, summary), and receive new guiding questions to continue the interview or finalize the story. UI states (idle, recording, processing, showing_analysis) must be managed.

aiSpecRequirements.title: Offline-First Story Archiving
aiSpecRequirements.description: The application shall support offline-first functionality for story archiving, utilizing IndexedDB or localStorage for local data persistence. This ensures stories can be captured and managed without constant internet connectivity.

aiSpecRequirements.title: GDPR-Compliant Data Handling and Consent
aiSpecRequirements.description: The system shall be fully GDPR-compliant, ensuring local storage of data for MVP and implementing explicit opt-in consent flows for any story export or publication. Data privacy is paramount for user trust.

aiSpecRequirements.title: Story Metadata Tagging and Structuring
aiSpecRequirements.description: The system shall enable the application of rich metadata to stories, including geo-tagging, temporal structuring, dialect capture, and general tags. This enhances the discoverability and historical value of the archived stories.

aiSpecRequirements.title: Personal Story Management ('My Stories')
aiSpecRequirements.description: Users shall be able to view, edit, and manage their personal collection of archived stories through a dedicated 'My Stories Page' and 'Story Detail / Edit Page'. This includes reviewing transcripts, summaries, and associated metadata.

aiSpecRequirements.title: Story Export and Sharing Capabilities
aiSpecRequirements.description: The system shall provide functionality to export and share stories in various formats, including PDF, Podcast, and Timeline. This fulfills the public and private purposes of the digital archive.

aiSpecRequirements.title: Multilingual User Interface (i18n)
aiSpecRequirements.description: The user interface shall support multiple languages, starting with German and English, with the ability for users to switch languages and persist their preference using local storage. This improves usability for a diverse audience.

aiSpecRequirements.title: Public Story Archive and Viewing
aiSpecRequirements.description: The system shall provide a 'Public Archive Page' and 'Public Story View Page' allowing public users to explore and view stories that have been explicitly consented for public sharing. This supports cultural and historical engagement.

aiSpecRequirements.title: Containerized Development Environment
aiSpecRequirements.description: The project shall utilize Docker and Docker Compose to provide a consistent and easily reproducible development environment for both frontend and backend services. This streamlines setup and deployment.

aiSpecRequirements.title: Secure API Key Management
aiSpecRequirements.description: The application shall manage sensitive API keys (e.g., for LLM providers) securely, utilizing environment variables and `.env` files, ensuring they are not hardcoded or committed to version control.

aiSpecRequirements.title: Robust Error Handling and UI Feedback
aiSpecRequirements.description: The system shall implement comprehensive error handling for API calls, microphone access, and other critical operations, providing clear feedback to the user and managing UI state transitions gracefully.

aiSpecRequirements.title: Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS) Configuration
aiSpecRequirements.description: The backend API shall be configured with appropriate CORS headers to allow communication with the frontend application, especially when running in separate containers or domains during development.

aiSpecRequirements.title: Microphone Access and Audio Recording
aiSpecRequirements.description: The frontend shall securely request and manage microphone permissions from the user's browser, enabling the capture of audio for story recording using the MediaRecorder API.

aiSpecRequirements.title: Performance of AI and STT Processing
aiSpecRequirements.description: The AI-guided interview and voice-to-text transcription processes shall be optimized for performance to ensure minimal latency and a smooth user experience, particularly for real-time interaction.

aiSpecRequirements.title: Scalability for Future Cloud Deployment
aiSpecRequirements.description: While the MVP is local-only, the system architecture shall consider future scalability to support cloud hosting (e.g., STACKIT/SICOS BW) and a growing number of users and archived stories.

aiSpecRequirements.title: Admin and Partner Portal Functionality
aiSpecRequirements.description: The system shall eventually include restricted access pages for administrators, content moderators, and institutional partners to manage content, users, and specific collections, ensuring quality control and collaboration.

aiSpecRequirements.title: Pricing and Subscription Management
aiSpecRequirements.description: The application shall incorporate a 'Pricing & Subscription Page' and related backend logic to manage private archive subscriptions and corporate storytelling packages, supporting the defined business model.

content.content:
## Requirements Overview

Storycatcher II is a digital archiving application designed to capture, preserve, and share personal stories. The system prioritizes user privacy through a local-first, GDPR-compliant approach, while leveraging AI for guided interviews and robust voice-to-text transcription. It aims to provide an intuitive experience for users to record, manage, and optionally share their narratives.

### Requirements Categorization and Priority

| ID    | Type      | Priority  | Description Summary                                          |
| :---- | :-------- | :-------- | :----------------------------------------------------------- |
| 2285  | backend   | critical  | User Registration and Authentication                         |
| 2286  | backend   | critical  | AI-Guided Interview Assistant                                |
| 2287  | backend   | critical  | Voice-to-Text Transcription (Local-First)                    |
| 2288  | frontend  | critical  | Interactive Story Capture Loop                               |
| 2289  | frontend  | critical  | Offline-First Story Archiving                                |
| 2290  | security  | critical  | GDPR-Compliant Data Handling and Consent                     |
| 2300  | frontend  | critical  | Microphone Access and Audio Recording                        |
| 2291  | backend   | high      | Story Metadata Tagging and Structuring                       |
| 2292  | frontend  | high      | Personal Story Management ('My Stories')                     |
| 2293  | backend   | high      | Story Export and Sharing Capabilities                        |
| 2294  | frontend  | high      | Multilingual User Interface (i18n)                           |
| 2296  | backend   | high      | Containerized Development Environment                        |
| 2297  | security  | high      | Secure API Key Management                                    |
| 2295  | frontend  | medium    | Public Story Archive and Viewing                             |
| 2298  | frontend  | medium    | Robust Error Handling and UI Feedback                        |
| 2299  | backend   | medium    | Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS) Configuration           |
| 2301  | backend   | medium    | Performance of AI and STT Processing                         |
| 2302  | backend   | low       | Scalability for Future Cloud Deployment                      |
| 2303  | backend   | low       | Admin and Partner Portal Functionality                       |
| 2304  | backend   | low       | Pricing and Subscription Management                          |

## Functional Requirements

### Core Business Functionality
*   **User Registration and Authentication (2285):** The system shall enable secure user registration and login, serving as the primary access point for personalized story archiving.
*   **AI-Guided Interview Assistant (2286):** The system shall provide an AI-driven interview process, utilizing the 5W questioning method to prompt users based on processed audio segments, facilitating story capture.
*   **Voice-to-Text Transcription (2287):** The system shall perform voice-to-text transcription of audio using local-first STT engines (Whisper/Vosk) to process interviews on-device.
*   **Story Metadata Tagging and Structuring (2291):** The system shall allow applying rich metadata to stories, including geo-tagging, temporal data, dialect, and general tags, to enhance discoverability.
*   **Story Export and Sharing Capabilities (2293):** The system shall support exporting and sharing stories in PDF, Podcast, and Timeline formats, enabling both private and public dissemination.

### User Interaction and Interface Requirements
*   **Interactive Story Capture Loop (2288):** The frontend shall manage UI states (idle, recording, processing, showing_analysis) to facilitate an interactive loop for recording, processing, displaying analysis (transcript, summary), and receiving new guiding questions.
*   **Personal Story Management ('My Stories') (2292):** Users shall be able to view, edit, and manage their archived stories, including reviewing transcripts, summaries, and metadata, via dedicated pages.
*   **Public Story Archive and Viewing (2295):** The system shall provide public access pages for exploring and viewing stories explicitly consented for public sharing.
*   **Microphone Access and Audio Recording (2300):** The frontend shall securely request and manage microphone permissions, enabling audio capture via the MediaRecorder API.
*   **Multilingual User Interface (i18n) (2294):** The UI shall support multiple languages (German, English initially), allowing users to switch and persist their language preference.

### Data Processing and Management Requirements
*   **Offline-First Story Archiving (2289):** The application shall support offline functionality for story archiving using IndexedDB or localStorage for local data persistence.

### Integration and Workflow Requirements
*   **Admin and Partner Portal Functionality (2303):** (Future) The system shall include restricted access pages for administrators, content moderators, and institutional partners for content and user management.
*   **Pricing and Subscription Management (2304):** (Future) The application shall incorporate a 'Pricing & Subscription Page' and backend logic for managing subscriptions.

## Non-Functional Requirements

### Performance and Scalability Requirements
*   **Performance of AI and STT Processing (2301):** AI-guided interview and voice-to-text processes shall be optimized for minimal latency and a smooth user experience.
*   **Scalability for Future Cloud Deployment (2302):** The system architecture shall consider future scalability for cloud hosting and a growing user base.

### Security and Compliance Requirements
*   **GDPR-Compliant Data Handling and Consent (2290):** (Detailed in separate section)
*   **Secure API Key Management (2297):** (Detailed in separate section)

### Usability and Reliability Requirements
*   **Robust Error Handling and UI Feedback (2298):** The system shall implement comprehensive error handling for API calls and microphone access, providing clear user feedback.
*   **Containerized Development Environment (2296):** Docker and Docker Compose shall be used to provide a consistent and reproducible development environment.
*   **Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS) Configuration (2299):** The backend API shall be configured with appropriate CORS headers to allow frontend communication.

## Requirements Analysis

### Mermaid Diagram Showing Requirement Relationships

```mermaid
graph TD
    A["2285 - User Auth"] --> B["2288 - Interactive Capture Loop"];
    B --> C["2300 - Microphone Access"];
    C --> D["2287 - Voice-to-Text"];
    D --> E["2286 - AI-Guided Interview"];
    E --> B;
    D --> F["2291 - Story Metadata Tagging"];
    F --> G["2292 - My Stories"];
    E --> G;
    G --> H["2293 - Story Export/Sharing"];
    H --> I["2295 - Public Archive"];
    J["2290 - GDPR Compliance"] --"Impacts"--> A;
    J --"Impacts"--> D;
    J --"Impacts"--> G;
    J --"Impacts"--> H;
    J --"Impacts"--> I;
    K["2289 - Offline-First Archiving"] --"Supports"--> G;
    L["2297 - Secure API Key Management"] --"Supports"--> E;
    M["2301 - AI/STT Performance"] --"Optimizes"--> D;
    M --"Optimizes"--> E;
    N["2298 - Error Handling"] --"Improves"--> B;
    N --"Improves"--> G;
    O["2294 - Multilingual UI"] --"Enhances"--> B;
    O --"Enhances"--> G;
    O --"Enhances"--> I;
    P["2296 - Containerized Dev"] --"Facilitates"--> A;
    P --"Facilitates"--> D;
    P --"Facilitates"--> L;
    Q["2299 - CORS Config"] --"Enables"--> A;
    Q --"Enables"--> D;
    R["2302 - Scalability"] --"Future"--> A;
    R --"Future"--> G;
    S["2303 - Admin Portal"] --"Future"--> G;
    T["2304 - Pricing/Subscription"] --"Future"--> A;
```

### Priority Matrix and Acceptance Criteria

**Priority Matrix:** Requirements are categorized into Critical, High, Medium, and Low priorities. Critical requirements are essential for the MVP and core functionality. High priority items are vital for a complete and robust user experience. Medium priority items enhance usability and prepare for future growth, while Low priority items are future considerations for later phases.

**Acceptance Criteria:** For each requirement, acceptance will be based on:
*   **Functional Completeness:** All specified features are implemented and operate as described.
*   **Performance:** The system meets defined performance benchmarks, particularly for AI/STT processing.
*   **Security:** Adherence to all security protocols, including secure data handling and API key management.
*   **Compliance:** Full compliance with GDPR regulations regarding data privacy and consent.
*   **Usability:** The UI is intuitive, responsive, and provides clear feedback, supporting multilingual preferences.
*   **Reliability:** The system handles errors gracefully and maintains data integrity, especially in offline scenarios.

## Security & Compliance Requirements

### Security Requirements
*   **Secure User Registration and Authentication (2285):** Implement robust authentication mechanisms (e.g., password hashing, secure token management) to protect user accounts from unauthorized access.
*   **Secure API Key Management (2297):** All sensitive API keys for external services (e.g., LLM providers) must be stored and accessed securely using environment variables or a secrets management system, preventing hardcoding or inclusion in version control.
*   **Secure Microphone Access (2300):** Microphone access must be requested explicitly from the user and managed securely by the browser, adhering to standard web security practices.
*   **Data Integrity and Confidentiality:** Ensure data stored locally (IndexedDB/localStorage) is protected from unauthorized access or tampering, though explicit encryption is not specified for MVP.

### Compliance Frameworks and Regulations
*   **GDPR (General Data Protection Regulation) (2290):** The system must be fully compliant with GDPR, specifically:
    *   **Data Minimization:** Only collect data necessary for core functionality.
    *   **Local Data Storage:** For MVP, user story data must be stored locally on the user's device.
    *   **Explicit Consent:** For any story export or publication to a public archive, explicit, opt-in consent from the user is mandatory.
    *   **Right to Erasure/Access:** Users must have clear mechanisms to access, correct, or delete their personal data.

### Best Practice Implementation Guidelines
*   **Principle of Least Privilege:** Components and services should only have the minimum necessary permissions.
*   **Secure Coding Practices:** Adhere to OWASP Top 10 guidelines for web application security.
*   **Regular Security Audits:** Conduct periodic security reviews and vulnerability assessments.
*   **Data Encryption in Transit:** Use HTTPS/TLS for all communication between frontend and backend to protect data during transmission.
*   **CORS Configuration (2299):** Implement strict CORS policies on the backend to prevent unauthorized cross-origin requests.

content.content:
# Project Overview: Storycatcher II

## Executive Summary

**Project Name:** Storycatcher II

Storycatcher II is a JavaScript-based application designed to facilitate the secure and private capture, management, and presentation of personal stories. As a second iteration, it emphasizes enhanced user experience, robust data privacy, and intelligent assistance.

**Purpose and Key Objectives:** The primary purpose is to provide a platform for individuals to digitally archive their personal narratives. Key objectives include establishing secure user authentication, implementing an AI-guided interview process based on the 5W method, performing local-first voice-to-text transcription, enabling interactive story capture, ensuring offline-first data archiving, and strictly adhering to GDPR compliance by prioritizing local data handling.

**Target Audience and Expected Outcomes:** The primary target audience comprises individuals seeking a secure and structured way to document their life stories. Future expansion may include cultural institutions or businesses interested in corporate storytelling. Expected outcomes are a user-friendly, private, and efficient tool that empowers users to preserve their heritage and memories digitally.

**Business Value and Success Criteria:** Storycatcher II offers significant business value by addressing the growing demand for digital legacy tools with strong privacy assurances. It facilitates cultural preservation and creates a foundation for potential subscription models for private archiving or corporate packages. Success will be measured by high user engagement in story capture, successful implementation of GDPR-compliant local data storage, accuracy and performance of AI and STT processes, and seamless offline functionality.

## Project Description

**Problem Statement:** Many existing digital storytelling tools either lack structured guidance for narrative capture or compromise user data privacy by relying heavily on cloud-based processing and storage. There is a need for a solution that combines intelligent assistance with a strong commitment to data sovereignty and user control.

**Proposed Solution:** Storycatcher II addresses these challenges by offering an AI-guided interview assistant to structure story capture, utilizing local-first voice-to-text transcription for enhanced privacy, and implementing an offline-first architecture for data persistence on the user's device. This approach ensures a private, guided, and accessible storytelling experience.

**Project Scope:**
*   **Included:**
    *   Secure User Registration and Authentication (2285)
    *   AI-Guided Interview Assistant (2286)
    *   Voice-to-Text Transcription (Local-First STT) (2287)
    *   Interactive Story Capture Loop (2288)
    *   Offline-First Story Archiving (2289)
    *   GDPR-Compliant Data Handling and Consent (2290)
    *   Story Metadata Tagging and Structuring (2291)
    *   Personal Story Management ('My Stories') (2292)
    *   Story Export and Sharing Capabilities (2293)
    *   Multilingual User Interface (i18n) (2294)
    *   Public Story Archive and Viewing (2295) - *Medium Priority*
    *   Containerized Development Environment (2296)
    *   Secure API Key Management (2297)
    *   Robust Error Handling and UI Feedback (2298)
    *   Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS) Configuration (2299)
    *   Microphone Access and Audio Recording (2300)
    *   Performance Optimization for AI and STT Processing (2301)
*   **Excluded (for MVP, but future considerations):**
    *   Scalability for Future Cloud Deployment (2302)
    *   Admin and Partner Portal Functionality (2303)
    *   Pricing and Subscription Management (2304)

**Key Deliverables:** A fully functional web application providing secure user authentication, an interactive AI-guided story capture process with local-first transcription, offline story archiving, and mechanisms for reviewing, managing, and exporting personal stories, all compliant with GDPR.

**Constraints:** The project is a JavaScript-based web application. A critical constraint is the "local-first" approach for sensitive data processing (STT) and storage (archiving), ensuring GDPR compliance by minimizing external data exposure.

## Stakeholders & Context

**Primary Stakeholders and Their Roles:**
*   **Users:** Individuals who will capture, manage, and share their personal stories. Their needs drive core features like privacy, ease of use, and guided storytelling.
*   **Project Team:** Developers, designers, and project managers responsible for the design, implementation, and deployment of Storycatcher II.
*   **Product Owner:** Defines the vision, prioritizes features, and ensures the product aligns with user needs and business objectives.
*   **Legal/Compliance Team:** Ensures adherence to GDPR and other relevant data privacy regulations.

**Business Context and Market Drivers:** The project operates within a growing market for digital personal archiving and cultural heritage preservation. Key drivers include increasing awareness of data privacy, demand for accessible storytelling tools, and the desire to preserve family histories and personal narratives digitally. The emphasis on "local-first" and GDPR compliance addresses significant market concerns regarding data sovereignty.

**High-Level Timeline and Phases:** The project will be developed iteratively, focusing on delivering a Minimum Viable Product (MVP) first, encompassing all critical and high-priority requirements. Subsequent phases will address medium and low-priority features, including scalability for cloud deployment and specialized portals.

## Requirements Overview

**Summary of Functional Requirements:**
*   **Critical:** User authentication, AI-guided interviews via 5W method, local-first voice-to-text transcription, interactive frontend for story capture, offline-first story archiving, comprehensive GDPR compliance, and secure microphone access. These form the core privacy-centric storytelling experience.
*   **High:** Rich metadata tagging for stories, dedicated personal story management (view/edit), diverse story export and sharing options, multilingual UI support (German/English), containerized development environment for consistency, and secure API key management. These enhance usability, manageability, and development efficiency.
*   **Medium:** Public archive for consented stories, robust error handling with clear UI feedback, and proper CORS configuration for API communication, performance optimization for AI/STT. These ensure broader accessibility, stability, and responsiveness.
*   **Low:** Future considerations include scalability for cloud deployment, administrator/partner portals, and pricing/subscription management, which address long-term growth and business models.

**Non-Functional Requirements:**
*   **Security & Privacy:** GDPR compliance (2290), secure API key management (2297), secure user authentication (2285), local-first data processing/storage (2287, 2289).
*   **Performance:** Optimized AI and STT processing for minimal latency (2301).
*   **Usability:** Multilingual user interface (2294), clear UI feedback and error handling (2298).
*   **Maintainability & Operability:** Containerized development environment (2296), consideration for future scalability (2302).
*   **Data Integrity:** Robust data persistence for offline archiving (2289).

**Key Assumptions:**
*   Users will have modern web browsers capable of supporting necessary APIs (e.g., MediaRecorder, IndexedDB).
*   Local-first STT engines (Whisper/Vosk) can be integrated efficiently into the backend environment to meet performance and GDPR requirements.
*   Backend infrastructure (even if private/on-premise) will be available for STT and AI processing.

**Dependencies:**
*   Frontend depends on secure backend API for authentication, AI guidance, and STT processing.
*   Backend depends on selected local-first STT engines (Whisper/Vosk) and potentially LLM providers for AI guidance.

## System Architecture

```mermaid
graph LR
    subgraph "User Device"
        A["Client - React/JavaScript UI"] --> B("Microphone Access / MediaRecorder API");
        A --> C("Local Storage - IndexedDB / localStorage");
    end

    subgraph "Backend Services - Node.js"
        D("API Gateway / Authentication") --> E("User Management Service");
        D --> F("Story Processing Service");
        F --> G("AI-Guided Interview Logic");
        F --> H("Local-First STT Engine - Whisper / Vosk");
        F --> I("Story Data Management");
    end

    subgraph "External Integration"
        J("LLM Provider API - for AI Guidance");
    end

    A -- "API Calls" --> D;
    B -- "Audio Stream" --> F;
    F -- "Text & Analysis" --> A;
    G -- "Question Generation" --> J;
    J -- "AI Responses" --> G;
    I -- "Store Story Metadata" --> K("Backend Database - PostgreSQL / MongoDB");

    style A fill:#e0f7fa,stroke:#00796b,stroke-width:2px
    style B fill:#e0f7fa,stroke:#00796b,stroke-width:2px
    style C fill:#e0f7fa,stroke:#00796b,stroke-width:2px
    style D fill:#c8e6c9,stroke:#388e3c,stroke-width:2px
    style E fill:#c8e6c9,stroke:#388e3c,stroke-width:2px
    style F fill:#c8e6c9,stroke:#388e3c,stroke-width:2px
    style G fill:#c8e6c9,stroke:#388e3c,stroke-width:2px
    style H fill:#c8e6c9,stroke:#388e3c,stroke-width:2px
    style I fill:#c8e6c9,stroke:#388e3c,stroke-width:2px
    style J fill:#fff8e1,stroke:#fbc02d,stroke-width:2px
    style K fill:#bbdefb,stroke:#1976d2,stroke-width:2px
```

## Interactive Story Capture Loop

```mermaid
sequenceDiagram
    actor User;
    participant Frontend;
    participant Backend;
    participant STT_Engine as "Local-First STT Engine";
    participant AI_Interviewer as "AI Interviewer";

    User->>Frontend: "Start Recording Story";
    Frontend->>Frontend: "Activate Microphone / MediaRecorder";
    Frontend->>User: "Display Recording UI";

    loop "Record Audio Segments"
        User->>Frontend: "Speak into Microphone";
        Frontend->>Frontend: "Capture Audio Segment";
        User->>Frontend: "Stop Recording Segment";
        Frontend->>Backend: "Send Audio Segment for Processing";
        Backend->>STT_Engine: "Request Transcription of Audio";
        STT_Engine-->>Backend: "Return Transcript Text";
        Backend->>AI_Interviewer: "Analyze Transcript / Generate Questions (5W)";
        AI_Interviewer-->>Backend: "Return Analysis and Next Question";
        Backend-->>Frontend: "Send Transcript, Summary, New Question";
        Frontend->>Frontend: "Store Transcript / Summary Locally (IndexedDB)";
        Frontend->>User: "Display Analysis and New Question";

        alt "User wants to continue"
            User->>Frontend: "Continue Recording";
        else "User wants to finalize"
            User->>Frontend: "Finalize Story";
            Frontend->>Backend: "Request Story Finalization";
            Backend-->>Frontend: "Confirm Story Archived";
            Frontend->>User: "Display 'Story Archived' Confirmation";
            break;
        end
    end
```

## Success Metrics & Risks

**How Success Will Be Measured:**
*   **User Adoption:** Number of registered users and active storytellers.
*   **Story Capture Rate:** Average number of audio segments and complete stories captured per active user.
*   **Data Privacy Compliance:** Successful internal and external audits confirming adherence to GDPR, especially regarding local data handling and consent flows.
*   **System Stability & Performance:** Uptime of backend services, latency of STT and AI processing, and responsiveness of the frontend.
*   **Offline Functionality:** Successful story capture and management when the device is offline, with seamless synchronization upon reconnection.

**Key Performance Indicators (KPIs):**
*   Percentage of users completing at least one full story.
*   Average latency for audio transcription and AI question generation.
*   STT accuracy rate (word error rate - WER).
*   Number of support tickets related to data privacy or technical issues.
*   User retention rate for story archiving.

**Major Risks and Mitigation Strategies:**
*   **Risk: GDPR Compliance Complexity:** Ensuring full compliance with "local-first" data handling and explicit consent can be intricate.
    *   **Mitigation:** Engage legal counsel early, implement privacy-by-design principles throughout development, develop clear and auditable consent flows for all data processing and sharing.
*   **Risk: Voice-to-Text Accuracy and Performance:** Local-first STT engines might not match cloud-based accuracy or speed, impacting user experience.
    *   **Mitigation:** Benchmark multiple local STT engines (Whisper, Vosk) to select the most performant and accurate. Optimize model deployment. Provide clear UI feedback during processing delays.
*   **Risk: Microphone Access and Browser Compatibility:** Issues with browser permissions or API differences could hinder audio recording.
    *   **Mitigation:** Implement robust permission handling with clear user prompts. Conduct extensive cross-browser and cross-device testing. Provide fallback mechanisms or clear error messages.
*   **Risk: User Adoption due to Privacy Concerns:** Despite "local-first," users may still be hesitant to trust a new platform with sensitive personal stories.
    *   **Mitigation:** Be transparent about data handling practices. Clearly communicate the "local-first" and GDPR compliance benefits. Build a strong privacy policy and user trust through consistent reliable performance.
*   **Risk: Scalability Challenges for Future Cloud Deployment:** While MVP is local-first, future cloud deployment might face architectural hurdles.
    *   **Mitigation:** Design the backend services with modularity and microservices principles from the outset. Use containerization (Docker) to ensure portability. Plan for future infrastructure scaling (e.g., message queues, load balancing).

## User Stories Overview

This document outlines the user stories for Storycatcher II, adopting an Agile methodology to incrementally deliver value. User stories, structured as "As a [user type], I want [functionality] so that [benefit]," facilitate understanding requirements from a user perspective, guiding development, testing, and prioritization.

### Epic-Level User Stories

Major features are grouped into the following epics:

*   **User Identity & Security:** Encompasses secure user access, authentication, and fundamental data privacy.
*   **Core Story Capture:** Focuses on the interactive process of recording, transcribing, and receiving AI-guided questions.
*   **Story Management & Archiving:** Covers local data persistence, organization, and review of personal narratives.
*   **Story Dissemination:** Deals with options for exporting and sharing stories, including public access.
*   **Platform Foundation:** Includes underlying technical requirements for development, performance, and future scalability.

### Story Mapping

The following diagram illustrates the primary user journey for story capture and management, linking key stages to their supporting requirements.

```mermaid
graph TD
    subgraph "User Journey: Story Capture & Management"
        A["User Access"] --> B["Start Story"];
        B --> C["Record/AI Guide"];
        C --> D["Review/Refine"];
        D --> E["Archive/Share"];
    end

    A --"Includes"--> "2285 - User Auth";
    B --"Includes"--> "2300 - Mic Access";
    C --"Includes"--> "2288 - Interactive Capture";
    C --"Includes"--> "2287 - Voice-to-Text";
    C --"Includes"--> "2286 - AI-Guided Interview";
    D --"Includes"--> "2292 - My Stories";
    D --"Includes"--> "2291 - Metadata Tagging";
    E --"Includes"--> "2289 - Offline Archiving";
    E --"Includes"--> "2293 - Export/Sharing";
    E --"Includes"--> "2295 - Public Archive";

    subgraph "Cross-Cutting Concerns"
        F["2290 - GDPR Compliance"]
        G["2294 - Multilingual UI"]
        H["2298 - Error Handling"]
        I["2301 - Performance"]
    end

    F --> A; F --> C; F --> E;
    G --> A; G --> B; G --> C; G --> D; G --> E;
    H --> C; H --> D;
    I --> C;
```

## Detailed User Stories

Stories are grouped by priority, reflecting the project's MVP focus. Story Points (SP) are relative estimates (1: trivial, 2: simple, 3: moderate, 5: complex).

### Critical Priority Stories

*   **ID: 2285 - User Registration and Authentication**
    *   As a new user, I want to register securely so that I can access personalized story archiving.
    *   As an existing user, I want to log in securely so that I can continue managing my stories.
    *   **Acceptance Criteria:** User can create/log in to account securely; Authentication protects user data.
    *   **SP:** 3. **Dependencies:** 2297.
*   **ID: 2286 - AI-Guided Interview Assistant**
    *   As a storyteller, I want AI-guided questions based on the 5W method so that my story capture is structured and comprehensive.
    *   **Acceptance Criteria:** AI prompts relevant questions after audio processing; Questions align with 5W method.
    *   **SP:** 5. **Dependencies:** 2287, 2301, 2297.
*   **ID: 2287 - Voice-to-Text Transcription (Local-First)**
    *   As a storyteller, I want my recorded audio transcribed to text using local-first STT so that my data remains on-device and private.
    *   **Acceptance Criteria:** Audio segments are accurately transcribed locally; Transcription adheres to GDPR.
    *   **SP:** 5. **Dependencies:** 2300, 2301, 2290.
*   **ID: 2288 - Interactive Story Capture Loop**
    *   As a storyteller, I want an interactive UI to record, process, display analysis, and receive new questions so that I can smoothly capture my narrative.
    *   **Acceptance Criteria:** UI clearly shows recording, processing, and analysis states; Displays transcript/summary; Presents next question.
    *   **SP:** 5. **Dependencies:** 2300, 2287, 2286, 2298.
*   **ID: 2289 - Offline-First Story Archiving**
    *   As a storyteller, I want to capture and archive stories offline so that I can work without constant internet access.
    *   **Acceptance Criteria:** Stories persist locally via IndexedDB/localStorage; Data syncs upon reconnection.
    *   **SP:** 3. **Dependencies:** 2290.
*   **ID: 2290 - GDPR-Compliant Data Handling and Consent**
    *   As a user, I want my data handled GDPR-compliantly with local storage and explicit consent so that my privacy is protected.
    *   **Acceptance Criteria:** Story data stored locally by default; Explicit opt-in for any export/publication.
    *   **SP:** 5. **Dependencies:** 2287, 2289, 2293, 2295.
*   **ID: 2300 - Microphone Access and Audio Recording**
    *   As a storyteller, I want the system to securely access my microphone so that I can record audio segments for my stories.
    *   **Acceptance Criteria:** Browser prompts for mic permission; Audio recorded via MediaRecorder API.
    *   **SP:** 2. **Dependencies:** 2288.

### High Priority Stories

*   **ID: 2291 - Story Metadata Tagging and Structuring**
    *   As a storyteller, I want to add rich metadata (geo-tagging, temporal, dialect, general tags) to my stories so that they are discoverable and historically valuable.
    *   **Acceptance Criteria:** User can apply various metadata types; Metadata is stored with the story.
    *   **SP:** 3. **Dependencies:** 2292.
*   **ID: 2292 - Personal Story Management ('My Stories')**
    *   As a storyteller, I want to view, edit, and manage my personal collection of archived stories so that I can review and refine my narratives.
    *   **Acceptance Criteria:** Dedicated 'My Stories' page exists; User can view/edit transcripts, summaries, and metadata.
    *   **SP:** 3. **Dependencies:** 2289, 2291.
*   **ID: 2293 - Story Export and Sharing Capabilities**
    *   As a storyteller, I want to export and share my stories in various formats (PDF, Podcast, Timeline) so that I can disseminate them privately or publicly.
    *   **Acceptance Criteria:** Options for PDF, Podcast, Timeline export are available; Sharing requires explicit consent.
    *   **SP:** 5. **Dependencies:** 2290, 2292.
*   **ID: 2294 - Multilingual User Interface (i18n)**
    *   As a user, I want to switch UI languages (German/English) and persist my preference so that I can use the application comfortably.
    *   **Acceptance Criteria:** UI supports German and English; Language preference is saved locally.
    *   **SP:** 2.
*   **ID: 2296 - Containerized Development Environment**
    *   As a developer, I want a containerized (Docker) development environment so that setup is consistent and reproducible.
    *   **Acceptance Criteria:** Docker Compose sets up frontend/backend services; Environment is consistent across machines.
    *   **SP:** 3.
*   **ID: 2297 - Secure API Key Management**
    *   As a developer, I want API keys managed securely via environment variables so that sensitive information is protected from version control.
    *   **Acceptance Criteria:** API keys loaded from .env files; No hardcoded keys in source.
    *   **SP:** 2. **Dependencies:** 2286.

### Medium Priority Stories

*   **ID: 2295 - Public Story Archive and Viewing**
    *   As a public user, I want to explore and view publicly shared stories so that I can engage with cultural content.
    *   **Acceptance Criteria:** Public archive page exists; Public stories are viewable without login.
    *   **SP:** 3. **Dependencies:** 2293, 2290.
*   **ID: 2298 - Robust Error Handling and UI Feedback**
    *   As a user, I want clear feedback and graceful error handling during operations so that I understand system status and issues.
    *   **Acceptance Criteria:** API call errors are handled; Microphone access errors are managed; UI state updates clearly.
    *   **SP:** 2.
*   **ID: 2299 - Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS) Configuration**
    *   As a developer, I want the backend API configured with correct CORS headers so that frontend/backend communication works seamlessly.
    *   **Acceptance Criteria:** CORS allows frontend access; Prevents cross-origin issues during development/production.
    *   **SP:** 1.
*   **ID: 2301 - Performance of AI and STT Processing**
    *   As a storyteller, I want fast AI and STT processing so that my interview experience is smooth and low-latency.
    *   **Acceptance Criteria:** STT and AI processing latency is minimal; User experience feels responsive.
    *   **SP:** 3. **Dependencies:** 2286, 2287.

### Low Priority Stories (Future Considerations)

*   **ID: 2302 - Scalability for Future Cloud Deployment**
    *   As a system architect, I want the system designed for future cloud scalability so that it can grow with user base and data.
    *   **Acceptance Criteria:** Architecture supports cloud deployment patterns; Services are modular.
    *   **SP:** 1.
*   **ID: 2303 - Admin and Partner Portal Functionality**
    *   As an administrator, I want access to restricted pages for content and user management so that I can moderate the platform.
    *   **Acceptance Criteria:** Admin portal exists; Provides user/content management.
    *   **SP:** 1. **Dependencies:** 2285.
*   **ID: 2304 - Pricing and Subscription Management**
    *   As a business, I want pricing and subscription management functionality so that I can monetize private archiving and corporate packages.
    *   **Acceptance Criteria:** Pricing page exists; Subscription logic implemented.
    *   **SP:** 1. **Dependencies:** 2285.

## Story Organization

Stories are organized by the Epics defined above and further prioritized as Critical, High, Medium, and Low. Critical stories form the core MVP. High priority stories enhance the core experience. Medium and Low priority stories are planned for subsequent phases.

*   **User Persona Mapping:**
    *   **Storyteller:** Primary user, interacting with all core capture and management features (2285, 2286, 2287, 2288, 2289, 2291, 2292, 2293, 2300, 2301).
    *   **Public User:** Views publicly shared stories (2295).
    *   **Developer:** Focuses on infrastructure and technical enablers (2296, 2297, 2299).
    *   **Administrator/Partner:** Future roles for content and user management (2303).
    *   **Business:** Future role for monetization (2304).

*   **Workflow and Process Integration:** Critical stories drive the main user workflow from registration to story capture and initial management. Dependencies ensure a logical build order, with foundational elements (e.g., authentication, microphone access) preceding interactive components. Cross-cutting concerns like GDPR (2290), multilingual support (2294), and error handling (2298) are integrated throughout the development process.

## Access Control and Security Stories

Security and access control are paramount, especially given the GDPR compliance requirement.

*   **User Stories Requiring Explicit Permissions:**
    *   **2285 - User Registration and Authentication:** Requires authentication to access any personalized features.
    *   **2290 - GDPR-Compliant Data Handling and Consent:** Explicit opt-in consent is required for any story export or publication (2293, 2295).
    *   **2300 - Microphone Access and Audio Recording:** Requires explicit user permission via browser prompts.
    *   **2292 - Personal Story Management ('My Stories'):** Access is restricted to the logged-in user for their own stories.
    *   **2303 - Admin and Partner Portal Functionality:** (Future) Access will be restricted to authorized admin/partner users.

*   **Actions Protected by Segregation of Duty Requirements:**
    *   For the MVP, explicit segregation of duties is not a primary concern beyond basic user/admin roles. Future Admin/Partner portals (2303) will introduce distinct roles for content moderation versus user management.

*   **Actions Requiring Audit Log or Audit Trail:**
    *   While not explicitly detailed for MVP, future enhancements for Admin/Partner portals (2303) and critical data operations (e.g., story deletion, consent changes related to 2290) would benefit from audit logging to track user and system actions for compliance and accountability.

*   **Role-Based Access Control Requirements:**
    *   **User Role:** Can register, log in, capture stories, manage their own stories, and optionally consent to public sharing.
    *   **Public Role:** Can view publicly consented stories (2295) without authentication.
    *   **Admin/Partner Roles (Future):** Will have elevated privileges for content moderation, user management, and potentially collection management (2303).

Storycatcher II leverages a modern, privacy-centric technology stack designed to deliver a robust, local-first, and AI-guided storytelling experience. The architecture emphasizes data sovereignty, performance, and a streamlined development workflow.

## Technology Stack Overview

Storycatcher II employs a client-server architecture with a strong emphasis on local data processing and storage for privacy.

```mermaid
graph LR
    subgraph "User Device"
        A["Client - React/JavaScript UI"] --> B("Microphone Access / MediaRecorder API");
        A --> C("Local Storage - IndexedDB / localStorage");
    end

    subgraph "Backend Services - Node.js"
        D("API Gateway / Authentication") --> E("User Management Service");
        D --> F("Story Processing Service");
        F --> G("AI-Guided Interview Logic");
        F --> H("Local-First STT Engine - Whisper / Vosk");
        F --> I("Story Data Management");
    end

    subgraph "External Integration"
        J("LLM Provider API - for AI Guidance");
    end

    A -- "API Calls (HTTPS/TLS)" --> D;
    B -- "Audio Stream" --> F;
    F -- "Text & Analysis" --> A;
    G -- "Question Generation" --> J;
    J -- "AI Responses" --> G;
    I -- "Store Story Metadata" --> K("Backend Database - PostgreSQL / MongoDB");

    style A fill:#e0f7fa,stroke:#00796b,stroke-width:2px
    style B fill:#e0f7fa,stroke:#00796b,stroke-width:2px

    style J fill:#fff8e1,stroke:#fbc02d,stroke-width:2px
    style K fill:#bbdefb,stroke:#1976d2,stroke-width:2px
```

**Technology Selection Principles and Criteria:**
*   **GDPR Compliance (2290):** Prioritizing local-first data processing and storage.
*   **Performance (2301):** Optimizing AI and STT processes for minimal latency.
*   **JavaScript Ecosystem:** Leveraging a unified language for both frontend and backend for consistency and developer efficiency.
*   **Containerization (2296):** Ensuring consistent and reproducible development environments.
*   **Security (2297):** Implementing secure API key management and data handling.
*   **Open Standards:** Utilizing browser-native APIs where possible (e.g., MediaRecorder, IndexedDB).

**Integration and Compatibility Considerations:**
Frontend and backend communicate via RESTful API calls over HTTPS/TLS. The backend integrates local-first STT engines and external LLM providers. CORS configuration (2299) is essential for seamless communication, especially during development.

## Frontend Technologies

*   **Frontend Framework:** React.js / JavaScript UI (Artifact 1 - System Architecture)
    *   Chosen for building interactive user interfaces (2288) and single-page applications.
*   **Local Data Persistence:** IndexedDB / localStorage (Artifact 1 - System Architecture, 2289)
    *   Critical for offline-first story archiving (2289) and GDPR-compliant local data handling (2290).
*   **Audio Recording:** MediaRecorder API (2300)
    *   Standard browser API for secure microphone access and audio capture.
*   **Internationalization:** i18n libraries (2294)
    *   For supporting multilingual user interfaces (German and English initially).
*   **Build Tools:** Standard JavaScript bundlers (e.g., Webpack/Vite implied by React ecosystem)
    *   To compile, bundle, and optimize frontend assets.

## Backend Technologies

*   **Runtime Environment:** Node.js (Artifact 1 - System Architecture)
    *   Enables a unified JavaScript stack across frontend and backend.
*   **Web Framework:** Express.js (Implied by Node.js for API services)
    *   For building RESTful APIs for user authentication, story processing, and data management.
*   **Authentication and Authorization:** JWT-based authentication (Implied by 2285 - User Registration and Authentication)
    *   For secure user login and API access control.
*   **Voice-to-Text (STT) Engine:** Whisper / Vosk (Artifact 1 - System Architecture, 2287)
    *   Selected for local-first transcription to ensure GDPR compliance and data privacy (2290).
*   **AI-Guided Interview Logic:** Custom Node.js modules integrating with LLM Provider API (2286)
    *   Implements the 5W questioning method and text analysis.
*   **LLM Integration:** External LLM Provider API (Artifact 1 - System Architecture, 2286)
    *   For AI guidance and question generation, with secure API key management (2297).
*   **CORS Configuration:** Express.js CORS middleware (2299)
    *   To manage cross-origin resource sharing between frontend and backend.

## Data and Storage Solutions

*   **Backend Database:** PostgreSQL / MongoDB (Artifact 1 - System Architecture)
    *   PostgreSQL (relational) or MongoDB (NoSQL) for storing user data, story metadata (2291), and transcripts/summaries that are not strictly local-only.
*   **Frontend Local Storage:** IndexedDB / localStorage (2289, 2290)
    *   Primary storage for user story data, transcripts, and summaries on the user's device.

## Infrastructure and DevOps

*   **Containerization:** Docker and Docker Compose (2296)
    *   For creating consistent, isolated, and reproducible development and deployment environments for both frontend and backend services.
*   **Deployment and Hosting:** Docker containers (MVP)
    *   For the MVP, deployment is container-based. Future plans include cloud hosting (e.g., STACKIT/SICOS BW, 2302).
*   **Secure API Key Management:** Environment variables and `.env` files (2297)
    *   To securely store and load sensitive API keys for LLM providers and other services.
*   **Communication Security:** HTTPS/TLS (Artifact 2 - Security Best Practices)
    *   Ensuring encrypted communication between the frontend and backend.

## Technology Justification

*   **React.js (Frontend Framework):** Chosen for its component-based architecture, enabling the interactive story capture loop (2288) and complex UI states, including multilingual support (2294) and robust error feedback (2298).
*   **Node.js / Express.js (Backend Runtime/Framework):** Provides a unified JavaScript development experience (Artifact 1), facilitating faster development and easier context switching. It's well-suited for building the API gateway (2285), processing audio streams, and managing AI/STT logic (2286, 2287).
*   **IndexedDB / localStorage (Frontend Storage):** Directly supports the critical requirement for offline-first story archiving (2289) and GDPR-compliant local data handling (2290), ensuring user data remains on the device by default.
*   **Whisper / Vosk (Local-First STT Engine):** Essential for fulfilling the critical requirement of local-first voice-to-text transcription (2287), directly addressing GDPR compliance (2290) by minimizing data transfer off-device.
*   **PostgreSQL / MongoDB (Backend Database):** Provides robust data persistence for user accounts (2285) and story metadata (2291), which may be shared or managed across sessions. The choice allows flexibility between relational integrity and schema flexibility.
*   **Docker and Docker Compose (Containerization):** Critical for establishing a consistent and easily reproducible development environment (2296), streamlining setup for developers and ensuring parity between development and deployment stages.
*   **MediaRecorder API (Frontend Audio):** A standard browser API that securely requests and manages microphone permissions (2300), enabling audio capture directly within the browser, crucial for the interactive capture loop (2288).
*   **LLM Provider API (AI Guidance):** Powers the AI-guided interview assistant (2286) using the 5W questioning method. Its integration is managed securely (2297) to protect sensitive API keys.
*   **HTTPS/TLS (Communication Security):** Fundamental for securing data in transit between the frontend and backend, protecting user credentials and story data, a key aspect of overall security (2285, 2290).

content.content:
## Architecture Overview

Storycatcher II is a privacy-centric, JavaScript-based web application designed for secure personal story capture. Its core architectural principle is "local-first" data handling for sensitive information, ensuring GDPR compliance. The system uses a modular approach, separating frontend client, backend services, and external integrations.

**Architectural Principles and Design Patterns:**
*   **Local-First:** Prioritizes on-device data processing (STT) and storage (story archiving) to maximize user privacy and GDPR compliance (2287, 2289, 2290).
*   **Privacy-by-Design:** Integrates GDPR compliance (2290) and secure API key management (2297) from the outset.
*   **Modular Design:** Backend services are logically separated (User Management, Story Processing) to facilitate maintainability and future scalability (2302).
*   **Interactive Loop:** The frontend supports a dynamic recording, processing, and feedback cycle for guided interviews (2288).

**Technology Stack Integration and Rationale:**
The architecture leverages a JavaScript ecosystem for both frontend (React) and backend (Node.js) for consistency and developer efficiency. Local-first Voice-to-Text (STT) engines like Whisper or Vosk are integrated directly into the backend to keep transcription on-premises, addressing privacy requirements (2287). IndexedDB/localStorage ensures offline story archiving (2289).

**Scalability and Performance Strategy:**
Performance optimization is critical for AI and STT processes to ensure a smooth user experience (2301). The modular backend design considers future cloud deployment and scaling (2302), allowing individual services to scale independently.

## Component Architecture

The system comprises a frontend client, a Node.js backend with distinct services, and an external LLM integration.

```mermaid
graph LR
    subgraph "User Device"
        A["Client - React/JavaScript UI"] --> B("Microphone Access / MediaRecorder API");
        A --> C("Local Storage - IndexedDB / localStorage");
    end

    subgraph "Backend Services - Node.js"
        D("API Gateway / Authentication") --> E("User Management Service");
        D --> F("Story Processing Service");
        F --> G("AI-Guided Interview Logic");
        F --> H("Local-First STT Engine - Whisper / Vosk");
        F --> I("Story Data Management");
    end

    subgraph "External Integration"
        J("LLM Provider API - for AI Guidance");
    end

    A -- "API Calls" --> D;
    B -- "Audio Stream" --> F;
    F -- "Text & Analysis" --> A;
    G -- "Question Generation" --> J;
    J -- "AI Responses" --> G;
    I -- "Store Story Metadata" --> K("Backend Database - PostgreSQL / MongoDB");

    style A fill:#e0f7fa,stroke:#00796b,stroke-width:2px
    style B fill:#e0f7fa,stroke:#00796b,stroke-width:2px
    style C fill:#e0f7fa,stroke:#00796b,stroke-width:2px
    style D fill:#c8e6c9,stroke:#388e3c,stroke-width:2px
    style E fill:#c8e6c9,stroke:#388e3c,stroke-width:2px
    style F fill:#c8e6c9,stroke:#388e3c,stroke-width:2px
    style G fill:#c8e6c9,stroke:#388e3c,stroke-width:2px
    style H fill:#c8e6c9,stroke:#388e3c,stroke-width:2px
    style I fill:#c8e6c9,stroke:#388e3c,stroke-width:2px
    style J fill:#fff8e1,stroke:#fbc02d,stroke-width:2px
    style K fill:#bbdefb,stroke:#1976d2,stroke-width:2px
```

**Component Responsibilities and Interfaces:**
*   **Client - React/JavaScript UI (2288, 2292, 2294, 2295, 2298, 2300):** Manages user interaction, audio recording via MediaRecorder API (2300), displays content, and handles local data persistence.
*   **Local Storage - IndexedDB/localStorage (2289, 2290):** Stores story data locally for offline functionality and GDPR compliance.
*   **API Gateway / Authentication (2285, 2299):** Entry point for all frontend requests, handles user authentication, and enforces CORS policies (2299).
*   **User Management Service (2285):** Manages user registration, login, and profile data.
*   **Story Processing Service (2286, 2287, 2291, 2293, 2301):** Orchestrates the core story capture loop. Receives audio, sends to STT, integrates AI for questions, handles metadata tagging (2291), and manages export/sharing (2293).
*   **AI-Guided Interview Logic (2286):** Implements the 5W questioning method, interacting with an external LLM.
*   **Local-First STT Engine (2287, 2301):** Performs voice-to-text transcription of audio segments on the backend server, ensuring data remains local.
*   **Story Data Management (2291, 2292):** Manages CRUD operations for story content and metadata with the backend database.
*   **Backend Database (PostgreSQL / MongoDB):** Persists user accounts and story metadata (not raw audio/transcripts for MVP).
*   **LLM Provider API (2286, 2297):** External service for AI question generation. API keys are securely managed (2297).

**Data Flow and Communication Patterns:**
*   **User to Frontend:** Direct interaction, microphone input (2300).
*   **Frontend to Backend:** RESTful API calls for authentication, story segment processing, and story management. Audio streams are sent to the backend (2288).
*   **Backend Internal:** Service-to-service communication for orchestration (e.g., Story Processing calling STT and AI logic).
*   **Backend to External LLM:** Secure API calls for AI guidance.
*   **Backend to Database:** Standard database queries.
*   **Backend to Frontend:** Transcripts, analysis, new questions, and confirmations are sent back (2288).

## Technology Stack and Infrastructure

*   **Frontend:** React (JavaScript) for interactive UI (2288, 2294). Leverages MediaRecorder API for audio capture (2300) and IndexedDB/localStorage for offline data persistence (2289).
*   **Backend:** Node.js (JavaScript) for API services. Integrates local-first STT engines (Whisper/Vosk) for on-premise transcription (2287). Database choice is flexible (PostgreSQL/MongoDB) for user and metadata storage.
*   **Infrastructure:** Docker and Docker Compose are used for a consistent and reproducible development environment (2296).
*   **Integration Patterns:** RESTful APIs for client-server communication. HTTPS/TLS is used for all data in transit for security.
*   **Communication Protocols:** HTTP/S for API calls, WebSockets potentially for real-time audio streaming (implicitly supported by MediaRecorder API and backend processing).
*   **Performance:** AI and STT processing are optimized for minimal latency (2301) using efficient algorithms and local execution.

## Security Architecture

**Security Principles and Threat Model Integration:**
Security is paramount, built on principles of privacy-by-design and least privilege. Key threats include unauthorized access to user accounts/data, data interception, and non-compliance with GDPR.

**Authentication and Authorization Architecture:**
*   **User Authentication (2285):** Secure login mechanisms (e.g., password hashing, token-based authentication) protect user accounts.
*   **Authorization:** Access to personal stories and management features is restricted to authenticated users (2292). Public archive viewing (2295) is open to all.

**Data Protection and Encryption Strategies:**
*   **Local-First Storage (2289, 2290):** The primary data protection strategy is keeping sensitive story content (audio, raw transcripts) on the user's device, minimizing server-side data exposure.
*   **Data in Transit:** All communication between frontend and backend uses HTTPS/TLS to encrypt data during transmission.
*   **Secure API Key Management (2297):** Sensitive API keys for external services are managed via environment variables, preventing hardcoding.
*   **Microphone Access (2300):** Browser-managed permissions ensure secure and explicit user consent for audio recording.

**Compliance and Regulatory Considerations:**
*   **GDPR Compliance (2290):** The system ensures local storage of MVP data, explicit opt-in consent for any story export or public sharing (2293, 2295), and mechanisms for users to manage their data.

## Architecture Security & Compliance

**Threat Model of the Architecture:**
*   **Unauthorized Access to User Accounts:** A user's account could be compromised, leading to unauthorized access to their story metadata and ability to trigger exports.
    *   **Mitigation:** Robust authentication (2285), password hashing, secure token management.
*   **Data Interception in Transit:** Data (e.g., audio segments, metadata) could be intercepted during transmission between frontend and backend.
    *   **Mitigation:** Mandatory HTTPS/TLS for all communication.
*   **Unauthorized Data Export/Sharing:** User stories could be shared publicly or exported without explicit consent.
    *   **Mitigation:** Strict GDPR-compliant consent flows (2290) for all export and public sharing features (2293, 2295).
*   **Compromise of API Keys:** Sensitive LLM API keys could be exposed, leading to unauthorized service usage or data breaches.
    *   **Mitigation:** Secure API key management using environment variables (2297).
*   **Malicious Microphone Access:** Unauthorized access to a user's microphone.
    *   **Mitigation:** Reliance on browser's secure permission model for MediaRecorder API (2300).

**Required Security Controls and Mitigations:**
*   **Authentication & Authorization:** Implement JWT or similar token-based authentication for user sessions (2285). Implement role-based access control for future admin/partner functionalities (2303).
*   **Data Storage:** Local-first storage (IndexedDB/localStorage) for critical story data (2289). Backend database stores only necessary user and story metadata (2291).
*   **Data in Transit:** Enforce HTTPS/TLS across all client-server and inter-service communication.
*   **Consent Management:** Implement clear, explicit, opt-in consent UI for sharing and export actions (2290, 2293, 2295).
*   **Secure Coding:** Adhere to OWASP Top 10 guidelines for web application security.
*   **CORS Configuration:** Properly configure CORS headers on the backend to restrict access to authorized origins (2299).
*   **Environment Variables:** Utilize environment variables for all sensitive configurations and API keys (2297).

**Shared Responsibility Model Definition:**
*   **User:** Responsible for device security, granting microphone permissions, and explicit consent decisions.
*   **Storycatcher II Application:** Responsible for secure application development, authentication, API key management, GDPR compliance (local-first, consent), data integrity, and secure communication.
*   **LLM Provider:** Responsible for the security and compliance of their AI service and API.

## Data Model Overview

The Storycatcher II data model is designed with a "local-first" approach for sensitive personal story content, complemented by a backend database for user management, story metadata, and publicly shared narratives. This hybrid architecture prioritizes GDPR compliance by minimizing cloud data exposure for private content while enabling features like user authentication, story organization, and public archiving.

Key entities include `User` (for authentication and preferences), `StoryMetadata` (for managing story details and public sharing status), `StoryTag` (for discoverability and categorization), and `InterviewQuestionLog` (for tracking the AI-guided interview process). Raw audio recordings and their full transcriptions are primarily stored locally on the user's device (e.g., in IndexedDB), with the backend processing these only transiently for AI analysis or for export/public sharing with explicit user consent.

Data flows from the frontend, where audio is captured and processed locally. Metadata about the story is then synchronized with the backend database. When a story is consented for public sharing or export, the backend facilitates the necessary transformations and storage of the derived content. The lifecycle of a story involves creation (local and metadata sync), ongoing management (local content, backend metadata), and optional sharing/export, all governed by explicit consent mechanisms.

## Entity-Relationship Diagram

```mermaid
erDiagram
    USER ||--o{ STORY_METADATA : "creates"
    STORY_METADATA ||--o{ STORY_TAG : "has"
    STORY_METADATA ||--o{ INTERVIEW_QUESTION_LOG : "generates"

    USER {
        string user_id PK
        string username
        string email
        string password_hash
        string preferred_language
        datetime created_at
        datetime updated_at
    }

    STORY_METADATA {
        string story_id PK
        string user_id FK
        string title
        string description
        boolean is_public
        string local_story_identifier
        datetime created_at
        datetime updated_at
    }

    STORY_TAG {
        string tag_id PK
        string story_id FK
        string tag_type
        string tag_value
    }

    INTERVIEW_QUESTION_LOG {
        string log_id PK
        string story_id FK
        string question_text
        datetime prompt_timestamp
        string ai_model_used
    }
```

## Entity Specifications

### USER
Represents a registered user of the Storycatcher II application.
*   **user_id**: String, Primary Key. Unique identifier for the user.
*   **username**: String, Unique, Not Null. User's chosen username for login.
*   **email**: String, Unique, Not Null. User's email address, used for login and communication.
*   **password_hash**: String, Not Null. Hashed and salted password for secure authentication.
*   **preferred_language**: String, Default 'en'. User's selected UI language (e.g., 'en', 'de').
*   **created_at**: Datetime, Not Null. Timestamp of user registration.
*   **updated_at**: Datetime, Not Null. Last timestamp of user profile update.
*   **Business Rules**: Each user must have a unique username and email. Passwords must be securely hashed.

### STORY_METADATA
Stores descriptive information about a story, managed on the backend. The actual audio and transcript content of the story resides primarily on the user's local device.
*   **story_id**: String, Primary Key. Unique identifier for the story metadata.
*   **user_id**: String, Foreign Key to USER. Links the story to its creator.
*   **title**: String, Not Null. User-defined title for the story.
*   **description**: Text, Optional. A brief summary or description of the story.
*   **is_public**: Boolean, Default False. Indicates if the user has explicitly consented to make this story public.
*   **local_story_identifier**: String, Not Null. A unique identifier generated on the client-side to link this backend metadata record to the full story content stored in the user's local IndexedDB.
*   **created_at**: Datetime, Not Null. Timestamp when the story metadata was first created.
*   **updated_at**: Datetime, Not Null. Last timestamp of story metadata update.
*   **Business Rules**: A story must belong to a user. `is_public` requires explicit user consent.

### STORY_TAG
Represents a tag associated with a story, enhancing discoverability and organization.
*   **tag_id**: String, Primary Key. Unique identifier for the tag entry.
*   **story_id**: String, Foreign Key to STORY_METADATA. Links the tag to a specific story.
*   **tag_type**: String, Not Null. Category of the tag (e.g., 'geo', 'temporal', 'dialect', 'general').
*   **tag_value**: String, Not Null. The actual content of the tag (e.g., 'Berlin', '1990s', 'Bavarian', 'Childhood').
*   **Business Rules**: Multiple tags can be associated with a single story.

### INTERVIEW_QUESTION_LOG
Logs the AI-generated questions presented to the user during the interactive story capture process.
*   **log_id**: String, Primary Key. Unique identifier for the log entry.
*   **story_id**: String, Foreign Key to STORY_METADATA. Links the question to the story being recorded.
*   **question_text**: Text, Not Null. The question prompted by the AI assistant.
*   **prompt_timestamp**: Datetime, Not Null. Timestamp when the question was presented.
*   **ai_model_used**: String, Optional. Identifier for the AI model that generated the question.
*   **Business Rules**: Records the sequence of AI interactions for a given story.

## Data Security and Privacy Considerations

The data model is built with GDPR compliance as a critical priority, emphasizing a local-first approach for sensitive content.

### Data Identification and Classification
*   **Confidential Data**: Raw audio recordings, full voice-to-text transcriptions, user passwords (hashed), personal story content (before explicit public consent). This data is primarily stored locally on the user's device.
*   **Internal Data**: User account information (username, email, preferred_language), story metadata (title, description, tags) when `is_public` is false. This data is stored on the backend.
*   **Public Data**: Story metadata and processed story content (e.g., exported PDF, podcast) that users have explicitly consented to make public (`is_public` is true).

### Analysis of Data Types Stored and Processed
*   **Personally Identifiable Information (PII)**: User registration details (email, username), and potentially geo-tags or other identifying information within story metadata.
*   **Sensitive Personal Data**: Voice recordings and their transcriptions contain personal narratives, opinions, and potentially sensitive biographical details. While processed by the backend's local-first STT engine, the raw audio and full transcripts are primarily retained on the user's device.

### Suitable Security Measures
*   **Authentication**: Robust mechanisms (e.g., password hashing, secure token management) for user accounts.
*   **Secure API Key Management**: Environment variables for sensitive API keys (e.g., LLM providers).
*   **Data in Transit**: All communication between frontend and backend uses HTTPS/TLS.
*   **CORS Configuration**: Strict CORS policies on the backend to prevent unauthorized cross-origin requests.
*   **Principle of Least Privilege**: Services and components have minimal necessary permissions.
*   **Secure Coding Practices**: Adherence to OWASP Top 10 guidelines.
*   **Local Data Protection**: Reliance on browser's IndexedDB security model, which isolates data per origin.

### Special Protection Requirements
*   **PII Data**:
    *   **Purpose**: Collected for user identification, personalized experience, and account management (Req 2285).
    *   **Consent**: User registration implies consent for basic account data processing. Explicit, opt-in consent is mandatory for any story export or publication (Req 2290, 2293, 2295).
    *   **Retention**: PII is retained as long as the user account exists. Users are provided mechanisms to access, correct, or delete their data (GDPR Right to Erasure/Access).
*   **Health Care Data**: Not applicable; the system is not designed to collect or process health-related information.
*   **Payment Data**: Not applicable for the MVP; pricing and subscription management (Req 2304) are future considerations.

content.content:
## Page Navigation Flow

The Storycatcher II application guides users through a clear set of pages, facilitating secure access, interactive story capture, and efficient management of personal narratives. The navigation flow emphasizes a user-centric design, allowing seamless transitions between core functionalities while maintaining privacy and data integrity.

```mermaid
graph TD
    subgraph "Public / Unauthenticated Access"
        LP["Landing Page"] --> LGP("Login Page");
        LP --> RP("Registration Page");
        LP --> PAP("Public Archive Page");
    end

    subgraph "Authenticated User Flow"
        LGP --> MSP("My Stories Page");
        RP --> MSP;
        MSP --> SCP("Story Capture Page");
        MSP --> SDSP("Story Detail / Edit Page");
        MSP --> LGP;
        SCP --> MSP;
        SDSP --> MSP;
        SDSP --> ESOP("Export / Share Options");
        ESOP --> SDSP;
        ESOP --> MSP;
    end

    subgraph "Public Story Viewing"
        PAP --> PSVP("Public Story View Page");
        PSVP --> PAP;
    end

    style LP fill:#f0f8ff,stroke:#3178c6,stroke-width:2px
    style LGP fill:#e0f7fa,stroke:#00796b,stroke-width:2px
    style RP fill:#e0f7fa,stroke:#00796b,stroke-width:2px
    style MSP fill:#c8e6c9,stroke:#388e3c,stroke-width:2px
    style SCP fill:#fff3e0,stroke:#e65100,stroke-width:2px
    style SDSP fill:#fffde7,stroke:#fbc02d,stroke-width:2px
    style ESOP fill:#ffe0b2,stroke:#fb8c00,stroke-width:2px
    style PAP fill:#e3f2fd,stroke:#1e88e5,stroke-width:2px
    style PSVP fill:#e3f2fd,stroke:#1e88e5,stroke-width:2px
```

**Overview of Page Hierarchy and User Flow:**

The application's navigation is structured around two primary states: unauthenticated and authenticated. The `Landing Page` serves as the initial entry point, directing users to `Login`, `Registration`, or the `Public Archive`. Upon successful login or registration, users are directed to the `My Stories Page`, which acts as their personalized dashboard. From `My Stories`, users can initiate `Story Capture`, manage individual stories via the `Story Detail / Edit Page`, or `Logout`. The `Story Capture Page` is an interactive loop for recording and processing audio. The `Story Detail / Edit Page` allows for metadata management and initiates `Export / Share Options`, which includes crucial GDPR consent steps. Publicly shared stories are accessible via the `Public Archive Page` and individual `Public Story View Pages`, which are available to both authenticated and unauthenticated users.

## Page Specifications

### Landing Page
*   **Purpose**: The initial entry point for the application, providing an overview and directing users to registration, login, or the public archive.
*   **Target Users**: New users, returning users, public users.
*   **Key Content**: Application branding, brief description of Storycatcher II's purpose (privacy-centric story capture), calls to action for registration, login, and exploring public stories.
*   **Actions Available**: "Register", "Log In", "Explore Public Archive".
*   **Navigation**:
    *   To `Registration Page` (via "Register").
    *   To `Login Page` (via "Log In").
    *   To `Public Archive Page` (via "Explore Public Archive").

### Registration Page
*   **Purpose**: Allows new users to create an account to access personalized story archiving features (Requirement 2285).
*   **Target Users**: New users.
*   **Key Content**: Form fields for username, email, password, password confirmation. Privacy policy link, terms of service checkbox.
*   **Actions Available**: "Register Account", "Back to Login".
*   **Navigation**:
    *   From `Landing Page`.
    *   To `My Stories Page` (on successful registration and automatic login).
    *   To `Login Page`.
    *   Displays error feedback (Requirement 2298) on failed registration.

### Login Page
*   **Purpose**: Enables existing users to securely log in to their accounts (Requirement 2285).
*   **Target Users**: Existing users.
*   **Key Content**: Form fields for username/email and password. "Forgot Password" link (if implemented in future, not explicit MVP req).
*   **Actions Available**: "Log In", "Register New Account".
*   **Navigation**:
    *   From `Landing Page`.
    *   From `Registration Page`.
    *   To `My Stories Page` (on successful login).
    *   To `Registration Page`.
    *   Displays error feedback (Requirement 2298) on failed login.

### My Stories Page
*   **Purpose**: Serves as the user's dashboard for viewing, editing, and managing their personal collection of archived stories (Requirement 2292, 2289).
*   **Target Users**: Authenticated storytellers.
*   **Key Content**: List of archived stories (titles, summaries, creation dates), options to sort/filter stories. Displays confirmation for archived stories (part of 2288).
*   **Actions Available**: "Start New Story", "Select Story" (to view/edit), "Logout".
*   **Navigation**:
    *   From `Login Page` or `Registration Page`.
    *   From `Story Capture Page` (after finalizing a story).
    *   From `Story Detail / Edit Page`.
    *   To `Story Capture Page`.
    *   To `Story Detail / Edit Page`.
    *   To `Login Page` (on logout).
    *   Supports offline-first display of stories (Requirement 2289).

### Story Capture Page
*   **Purpose**: Provides the interactive interface for recording audio segments, displaying AI-guided questions, and showing transcription/analysis (Requirement 2288).
*   **Target Users**: Authenticated storytellers.
*   **Key Content**: Microphone access prompt/status (Requirement 2300), recording controls (start, stop, pause), real-time or near real-time transcript display (Requirement 2287), AI-generated guiding questions (Requirement 2286), summary of current segment. UI states for idle, recording, processing, showing analysis (Requirement 2288).
*   **Actions Available**: "Start Recording", "Stop Recording Segment", "Continue Recording", "Finalize Story".
*   **Navigation**:
    *   From `My Stories Page`.
    *   To `My Stories Page` (on finalizing story).
    *   Displays robust error handling and UI feedback for microphone access or processing issues (Requirement 2298).

### Story Detail / Edit Page
*   **Purpose**: Allows users to view the full transcript and summary of a specific story, edit its metadata, and initiate export or sharing (Requirement 2292, 2291, 2293).
*   **Target Users**: Authenticated storytellers.
*   **Key Content**: Full story transcript, detailed summary, editable metadata fields (geo-tagging, temporal, dialect, general tags - Requirement 2291), story playback controls.
*   **Actions Available**: "Edit Metadata", "Save Changes", "Cancel Edit", "Export Story", "Share Story", "Delete Story".
*   **Navigation**:
    *   From `My Stories Page`.
    *   To `My Stories Page`.
    *   To `Export / Share Options` (on selecting export/share).

### Export / Share Options
*   **Purpose**: Presents options for exporting a story in various formats (PDF, Podcast, Timeline) and managing explicit consent for public sharing (Requirement 2293, 2290).
*   **Target Users**: Authenticated storytellers.
*   **Key Content**: Checkboxes/radio buttons for export formats (PDF, Podcast, Timeline). Clear GDPR consent form for public sharing, including opt-in confirmation (Requirement 2290).
*   **Actions Available**: "Select Format", "Grant Consent for Public Sharing", "Confirm Export/Share", "Cancel".
*   **Navigation**:
    *   From `Story Detail / Edit Page`.
    *   To `Story Detail / Edit Page`.
    *   To `My Stories Page` (after successful export/share confirmation).

### Public Archive Page
*   **Purpose**: Allows public users to browse and explore stories that have been explicitly consented for public sharing (Requirement 2295).
*   **Target Users**: Public users, authenticated users.
*   **Key Content**: Browseable list of publicly available stories, including titles, authors, summaries, and potentially metadata tags. Search and filter options.
*   **Actions Available**: "Select Story" (to view details).
*   **Navigation**:
    *   From `Landing Page`.
    *   To `Public Story View Page`.
    *   To `Login Page` / `Registration Page`.

### Public Story View Page
*   **Purpose**: Displays the full content of a single story that has been explicitly consented for public viewing (Requirement 2295).
*   **Target Users**: Public users, authenticated users.
*   **Key Content**: Full story transcript, summary, associated public metadata, author (if shared). No editing or export options.
*   **Actions Available**: "Back to Public Archive".
*   **Navigation**:
    *   From `Public Archive Page`.
    *   To `Public Archive Page`.
